Problem:
In the context of a heat conduction problem, assume a rod along the x-axis where the temperature distribution at time t is given by the function \( u(x,t) \), which satisfies the heat equation \( \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} = k\frac{\partial^2 u}{\partial x^2} \). We consider an integral transformation \( f(u) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-sx}u(x,0) \, dx \) (Fourier Transform) and study its impact on the solution when applied initially.

If an intervention by applying a different transformation \( g(u) = \int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-px}u(x,0) \, dx \) (another Fourier Transform with different parameter p) is conducted at \( t_1 \), will the endpoint \( u(x,T) \) for T > \( t_1 \) depend only on the heat conduction rate \( k \) and not on the transformations \( f(u) \) or \( g(u) \)?
Explanation: The intervention \( g(u) \) modifies the evolving function by a substantial architecture shift due to the integral operation with a different parameter \( p \). Both \( f(u) \) and \( g(u) \) influence the development of the temperature profile, thus affecting the endpoint \( u(x,T) \).
